question: Question_B_03_(b)
statement:
Let \emph{A} be a certain $2\times 3$ matrix. Suppose that using
elementary row operations, the matrix \emph{A} can be transformed into
the matrix

\[U = \begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 0 & -7 \\
0 & 1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}\]

Can you find the solution of $Ax = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$
with the given information? Justify your answer.
sols:
No, this is not possible. Elementary row operations change the right
hand side and hence, in general, solutions of \emph{Ax = b} are not
related to solutions of \emph{Ux = b}. Only in the special case of a
homogeneous system, when \emph{b = 0}, is this possible.

An easy way to see this is by a counter example. We will look at two
matrices \emph{A\textsubscript{1}} and \emph{A\textsubscript{2}} that
can both be row reduced to \emph{U}, but have different solutions to
$A\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$

Let us choose \emph{A\textsubscript{1} = U} and $A_2 = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 \\ 1 & 1 & -3
\end{bmatrix}$

\emph{A\textsubscript{2}} was obtained by adding the first row of
\emph{U} to the second row of \emph{U}. Hence, by subtracting row 1 from
row 2 in \emph{A\textsubscript{2}} gives \emph{U}, which shows that
\emph{A\textsubscript{2}} can be row reduced to \emph{U}.

Solving $A_1\mathbf{x}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$ we get

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 & | & 0
\end{bmatrix}\] with solution

\[\mathbf{x}_1 = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\-4\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0 \\0\end{bmatrix}\]

While solving $A_2\mathbf{x}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$
we get

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & -3 & | & 0
\end{bmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 & | & \color{red} -1\end{bmatrix}\] with solution

\[\mathbf{x}_2 = b\begin{bmatrix}7\\-4\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\ \color{red} -1\\0\end{bmatrix}\]

As we see, regardless of \emph{a} and \emph{b} we always find
$\mathbf{x}_1 \not= \mathbf{x}_2$. Thus using the given information, we
cannot tell which solution set is correct.

Another way to view this question is to notice that elementary row
operations combine to give us that

$\displaystyle A = EU$

where \emph{E} is an invertible matrix. Thus solving

$\displaystyle Ax = \begin{bmatrix}1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}$

Reduces to solving

$\displaystyle Ux = E^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}$

This last solution varies with the matrix \emph{E}. Notice that if the
vector on the right were the zero vector, then this matrix would not
matter (as it didn't in
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2013/Question B 03 (a)}{part
(a)}) but here it can make a huge difference. A concrete counter example
is given in solution 1.
hints:
If you were to solve a non-homogeneous system, would the right hand side
change as you do elementary row operations? Would this affect the
solution?
